Name: ArchiCrypt Live
Hidden containers: <ref name="ArchiCrypt">Secret-containers and Camouflage files ArchiCrypt Live Description</ref>

Name: BestCrypt
Multiple keys: <ref>Supported by the BestCrypt container format; see BestCrypt SDK</ref>
Two-factor authentication: <ref>Supported by the BestCrypt Volume Encryption software</ref>

Name: BitLocker
Custom authentication: <ref>BitLocker Drive Encryption: Value Add Extensibility Options</ref>

Name: CipherShed
Multiple keys: <ref>Although each volume encrypted with CipherShed can only have one active master key  it is possible to access its contents through more than one header. Each header can have a different password and/or keyfiles if any (cf. TrueCrypt FAQ: Is there a way for an administrator to reset a volume password or pre-boot authentication password when a user forgets it (or loses a keyfile)?)</ref><ref name="truecrypt.org"></ref>

Name: Cryptoloop
Pre-boot authentication: <ref name=dmcrypt-initrd>dm-crypt and cryptoloop volumes can be mounted from the initrd before the system is booted</ref>

Name: FreeOTFE
Custom authentication: <ref name=components>FreeOTFE has a modular architecture and set of components to allow 3rd party integration</ref>
Multiple keys: <ref name=keyfiles>FreeOTFE allows multiple keys to mount the same container file via encrypted keyfiles</ref>

Name: n-Crypt Pro
Passphrase strengthening: <ref name=ncrypt-bio>n-Crypt Pro does not use password authenticationâ€” biometric/USB dongle authentication only</ref>

Name: PGPDisk
Passphrase strengthening: <ref>PGP private keys are always protected by strengthened passphrases</ref>

Name: Svnd / Vnconfig
Passphrase strengthening: <ref>optional by using -K OpenBSD Manual Pages: vnconfig(8)</ref>

Name: TrueCrypt
Multiple keys: <ref name="truecrypt.org"/><ref>Although each volume encrypted with TrueCrypt can only have one active master key  it is possible to access its contents through more than one header. Each header can have a different password and/or keyfiles if any (cf. TrueCrypt FAQ: Is there a way for an administrator to reset a volume password or pre-boot authentication password when a user forgets it (or loses a keyfile)?)</ref>
